7:["$","section",null,{"className":"py-16","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"container mx-auto px-4","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"max-w-3xl mx-auto","children":[["$","h2",null,{"className":"text-3xl font-bold mb-6","children":["Living in ","Villa Crespo"]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-lg max-w-none text-muted-foreground leading-relaxed","children":[["$","p","0",{"className":"mb-4","children":["Villa Crespo is the open secret of Buenos Aires' expat scene. Bordering Palermo to the south, it offers much of the same walkability, food scene, and vibe — but at significantly lower rents. The neighborhood has been gentrifying steadily, with trendy restaurants and cafes popping up along Aguirre, Thames, and Gurruchaga streets. But unlike Palermo, Villa Crespo still retains its Argentine character","."]}],["$","p","1",{"className":"mb-4","children":["You'll find old-school almacenes (corner stores), traditional pizzerias, and neighbors who've lived here for decades. The Subte B line runs through the heart of the neighborhood (Malabia, Dorrego stations), providing excellent connectivity to downtown. Avenida Córdoba's outlet district offers some of the best shopping deals in the city for clothing and leather goods. The food scene is increasingly excellent — some of BA's best new restaurants have opened here specifically because rents allow for more creativity","."]}],["$","p","2",{"className":"mb-4","children":["For expats who want to be close to Palermo's amenities without paying Palermo prices, Villa Crespo is the answer. The main consideration is that it's still developing — some blocks are more polished than others.",""]}]]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"mt-12","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm
